data.title: Is there?
data.body: How do I customize the rename symbol's colours?

data.title: Integrated Terminal: Add path variables for cwd setting
data.body:
With the new multi-root folder capability it can be desirable to open an integrated terminal
using a CWD other than the root folder.

Adding path variables (subset of those used for the window title plus perhaps some for workspace folders)
would allow launching terminals in other locations more easily.

data.title: How to locate one of several files of the same name

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15
- OS Version: windows 7 x64

How to locate one of several files of the same name

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7886064/29545548-9078e304-8721-11e7-8c64-0aff792a3d21.png)
As shown, I want to match the "config.php" of "adsys/protected". In SublimeTextEditor, it is easily to  enter some keywords on the left side of the config.php to match the target. 
But VSCODE can't do that.

data.title: Add deepscan.io to trusted badge providers
data.body:
I wanted to add a badge for my VS Code extension project like:
[![DeepScan Grade](https://deepscan.io/api/projects/369/branches/577/badge/grade.svg)](https://deepscan.io/dashboard/#view=project&pid=369&bid=577)

But I can't package my extension due to svg issue, SVGs are restricted in README.md.

Please consider adding [deepscan.io](https://deepscan.io) to trusted badge provider.

data.title: [Code formatting] {{else if}} doesn't work in handlebars files
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Try to format the following code in `hbs` (Ember template) files
```hbs
{{#if conditionA}}
    Something when conditionA comes true
{{else if conditionB}}
     Otherwise, something when conditionB comes true
{{/if}}
```

Expected:
  Code indent like above.
Actually:
```hbs
  {{#if conditionA}}
    Something when conditionA comes true {{else if conditionB}} Otherwise, something when conditionB comes true
  {{/if}}
```

Reason:
```{{else if}}``` direction is not recognized as a block statement but regular handlebars tags.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: editor view - all branch close and open - feature missing
data.body:
I'm not sure whether this functionality does exist, but i haven't found it yet.

I have tried to open a carto project.mml, it's not supported, but i have realized that VSCode is smartly looking for tabs, so at the side bar i can close and open nodes.

For big files, does not necessary c++/html javascript etc., it would be helpful to be able to close all the nodes in the editor window and open it selectively what the collapse all does in the file browser.

data.title: Launch configuration is changed when debugging is started
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:05:38.342Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
open-html-in-browser|cod|0.1.21
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
vscode-nuget-package-manager|jmr|1.1.4
csharp|ms-|1.12.1
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.8
debugger-for-edge|msj|0.4.1
marko|pca|0.2.2
vim|vsc|0.9.0
---

A compound configuration may reference multiple launch configurations.
When such a compound configuration is selected for launch, (debug toolbar, DEBUG list) and the debugging session is started (F5) the selected configuration is changed to the last referenced launch configuration.

Subsequently, to restart the compound configuration one must first manually select the compound configuration in the DEBUG dropdown list.

The expected behavior is to retain the selected compound configuration after debugging is terminated.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a node launch configuration - "Launch Program"
2. Create a chrome launch configuration - "Launch Chrome"
3. Create a compound configuration consisting of the above - "Launch & Debug"
4. Select the compound - "Launch & Debug"
5. Start debugging - F5
6. Stop debugging - Shift-F5, Shift-F5

The selected configuration is now "Launch Program"
The expected behavior is for the selected configuration to be "Launch & Debug"

launch.json:
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Launch Program",
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}\\app.js",
      "protocol": "inspector"
    },
    {
        "name": "Launch Chrome",
        "type": "chrome",
        "runtimeArgs": [
          "--incognito"
        ],
        "request": "launch",
        "port": 9222,
        "url": "http://localhost:3000/",
        "sourceMaps": true,
        "webRoot": "${workspaceRoot}"
    }
  ],
  "compounds": [
      {
          "name": "Launch & Debug",
          "configurations": [ "Launch Program", "Launch Chrome" ]
      }
  ]
}

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No (not applicable)

data.title: Add contrast ratio to color picker
data.body:
Chrome DevTools recently added color contrasts to their color picker, which makes it much easier to do accessibility compliance.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/173559/29541833-9c0e2a6c-868b-11e7-88c3-4b3cf241b365.png)


We should add the same to ours.

Blog post: https://remysharp.com/2017/08/17/contrast-ratio-in-devtools

data.title: add an option to not use dbus: VScode randomly freezes inside docker containers trying to access a non existing dbus service
data.body:
- VSCode Version: all
- OS Version: any linux docker image

Synopsis: docker containers do not have systemd or dbus, normally. I use visual studio code inside a docker container. my docker host also has an Xserver running, so dbus is really not neeeded, I think. 

Create an option for the user to specify that he does not want that vscode communicates with `dbus` in any way on linux. 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. start vscode inside a centos docker container. 
2. watch it randomly freeze while trying to connect to a non existing dbus socket.

```text
[634:0821/185354.088216:ERROR:bus.cc(427)] Failed to connect to the bus: Failed to connect to socket /var/run/dbus/system_bus_socket: No such file or directory
libGL error:
No matching fbConfigs or visuals found
libGL error:
failed to load driver: swrast
[634:0821/185356.147724:ERROR:bus.cc(427)] Failed to connect to the bus: /bin/dbus-launch terminated abnormally without any error message
[634:0821/185356.230790:ERROR:bus.cc(427)] Failed to connect to the bus: /bin/dbus-launch terminated abnormally without any error message
[main 6:53:58 PM] IPC#vscode-workbenchLoaded
[634:0821/185359.037561:ERROR:bus.cc(427)] Failed to connect to the bus: /bin/dbus-launch terminated abnormally without any error message
[634:0821/185359.049355:ERROR:bus.cc(427)] Failed to connect to the bus: /bin/dbus-launch terminated abnormally without any error message
[main 6:53:59 PM] IPC#vscode-machineId
[main 6:53:59 PM] IPC#vscode:broadcast null vscode:changeColorTheme {"id":"vs-dark vscode-theme-defaults-themes-dark_plus-json","background":"#1e1e1e"}
[634:0821/185425.157883:ERROR:bus.cc(427)] Failed to connect to the bus: /bin/dbus-launch terminated abnormally without any error message
[634:0821/185425.162648:ERROR:bus.cc(427)] Failed to connect to the bus: /bin/dbus-launch terminated abnormally without any error message
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Feature: search up the directory hierarchy for .vscode settings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a workspace with a .vscode settings directory
2. Open a subdirectory in the workspace with VS Code
3. VS Code doesn't apply the parent directory's settings

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

The purpose of this feature is to let people open a project directory within a larger workspace (which contains multiple projects) and still retain the team's workspace-level VS Code settings. Put more abstractly: when I open a subdirectory in a workspace, I want VS Code to recognize I am in that workspace.

I'm mostly just wondering if it emmet can be a little smarter about when it makes it's suggestions? I really want to use it, but right now it's getting in my way 80% of the time.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: vscode.diff does not allow case insensitive comparison

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16257
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-color|ans|0.4.5



---

Issue is that the ````vscode.diff```` tool does not allow a case-insensitive diff.  The programming language I work with is case insensitive.  As such when I compare two programs I get a lot of false positives in the diff due to text case.

I have been using the extension found: https://github.com/ryu1kn/vscode-partial-diff.

However when I raised an issue there I was advised this simply made use of ````vscode.diff```` hence my raising this issue:  https://github.com/ryu1kn/vscode-partial-diff/issues/10

t2t

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Replace all instances off "Focussed" with "Focused" except ContextKey
data.body:
- Use Focused/focused consistently instead of Focussed (English version)
- Comments
- Constants, properties, variables
- Functions/methods

- Keep "findInputFocussed" ContextKey to not break existing when clauses.

export const CONTEXT_FIND_INPUT_FOCUSED = new RawContextKey<boolean>('findInputFocussed', false);

Addresses: #32521

data.title: Setting to disable find's auto-selection
data.body:
Thing that really annoys me:

- An editor is focused with **nothing selected**
- I hit Ctrl-F
- Whatever is under the cursor is selected and put into Find

Thing that I like:

- An editor is focused and **something is selected**
- I hit Ctrl-F
- Whatever is selected is put into find

**Please add a setting to disable the former.**

I like `editor.find.seedSearchStringFromSelection`. I simply don't want the editor to make a selection where none existed previously.

data.title: Uncaught exception when trying to restore a tab pointing at a deleted file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (0626479859787fa87c7c57ba19195b939050a843, 2017-08-21T05:17:04.920Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.0-32-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
lorem-ipsum|Tyr|1.0.0
sort-lines|Tyr|1.3.0
vscode-svgviewer|css|1.4.2
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
git-project-manager|fel|1.3.2
md-navigate|jri|0.0.1
vscode-scss|mrm|0.6.2
seti-icons|qin|0.1.3
Ruby|reb|0.15.0
vim|vsc|0.9.0

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

I believe this happens when you have an opened tab that's pointing at a file that has been deleted on disk. You can get into this state via hot exit as the tabs are not individually checked when they are restored, only when you try open them.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/29528505-1fc88a5e-8651-11e7-8f86-f262da992be1.png)


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/29528513-2506d0f2-8651-11e7-84f0-04c6052d2276.png)

The steps I used to get to this:

1. Open a folder with a saved workspace that contains a file that's been deleted
2. Ctrl+w multiple times

data.title: [git] Improve `stash pop` label
data.body:
VSCode Version: 1.16.0-insider (0626479859787fa87c7c57ba19195b939050a843)

I found a difficult  phrase to translate when translating.

[`Stash pop`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/bbe70bc9b930b0cd63d1b40720e516525db22e99/extensions/git/package.nls.json#L41) is the git command name and does not represent the action. Also, this command has 2 meaning; apply stash, remove it.  

So, it is difficult to translate correctly including these.  

Please change to an alternative label. 

Suggestions: 
Apply Stashed Changes And Delete - stash pop
(Apply Latest  Stashed Changes And Delete) - stash pop latest
